Describe causes - from most to least common for Dizzy When Standing Up.

Causes - From Most to Least Common

 1. Orthostatic Hypotension (Blood Pressure Drop When Rising)

 This is the most common cause overall, accounting for around 42% of all dizziness cases. When you stand up, 500-1000 ml of blood collects in your legs due to gravity. Normally, the body compensates by increasing heart rate and constricting blood vessels. In orthostatic hypotension, these mechanisms fail, and the brain temporarily receives too little blood.

 Who is most affected? Elderly over 65, people taking blood pressure medication, diabetics (24% prevalence), and Parkinson's patients (30-40% prevalence).

 Typical symptoms: Lightheadedness and unsteadiness occurring seconds to minutes after standing up. Many experience "graying out" or tunnel vision. Symptoms disappear when sitting down again. Important: Symptoms never occur when lying flat.

 2. BPPV (Crystal Disease)

 BPPV is the most common vestibular cause of position-related dizziness. Around 2.4% of the population experiences this during their lifetime, and the condition accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness consultations. Women are affected twice as often as men.

 BPPV occurs when small calcium crystals in the inner ear become dislodged and end up in the semicircular canals. This sends false rotation signals to the brain.

 Typical symptoms: Intense sensation of the room spinning. Episodes typically last 10-60 seconds and are triggered by head movements - including when turning over in bed. Nausea is common.

 3. Medication Side Effects

 Over 250 medications can cause orthostatic hypotension. The main culprits include
 Alpha blockers carry highest risk

 Tricyclic antidepressants give six times increased risk

 Diuretics

 All types of blood pressure medication

 Prevalence by Age Group

 Age Group 
 Prevalence 

 Under 50 years 
 ~5% 

 60+ years 
 22% 

 Over 70 years 
 30% 

 Nursing home residents 
 24-50%

Describe treatment options for Stress Fracture in the Foot.

Treatment

 

 Treatment depends on the fracture's location (low- vs. high-risk) and severity.

 Basic Principles

 
 Offloading

 Stop the activity that caused the fracture. Duration: 6-8 weeks for low-risk fractures

 

 
 Supportive Footwear

 Stiff shoes or walker boot to reduce loading

 

 
 Alternative Training

 Swimming, cycling, pool running - activities without loading

 

 
 Gradual Return

 Slow progression of loading when pain-free

 

 
 High-Risk Fractures

 For fractures in the 5th metatarsal (proximal) or navicular:

 
 Often need complete offloading with crutches

 Cast or walker boot for 6-12 weeks

 Surgery may be necessary if healing fails

 Close follow-up with control X-ray/MRI

 
 

 When Can I Start Running Again?

 
 Week 0-6

 No weight-bearing activity. Alternative training like swimming/cycling

 

 
 Week 6-8

 Gradual increase in walking. Pain-free walking before further progression

 

 
 Week 8-10

 Start with light jogging (walk-jog intervals)

 

 
 Week 10+

 Gradual increase in distance and intensity (max 10%/week)

Beskriv symptomer å mer enn bare utseende for Krum Rygg og Dårlig Holdning.

Symptomer å mer enn bare utseende

 Krum rygg handler ikke bare om hvordan du ser ut. Mange opplever en rekke plager som de ikke kobler til holdningen
 Nakke- og skulderproblemer

 Økt brystkrumning tvinger hodet fremover for å opprettholde horisontalt blikk. Dette overbelaster nakkemuskler og ledd, noe som kan føre til smerter mellom skulderbladene . Forskning viser at forward head posture medierer forholdet mellom brystkyfose og nedsatt nakkebevegelighet. Granito et al. (2012) dokumenterte at redusert brystmobilitet korrelerte med 23% redusert skulderbevegelighet.

 Hodepine

 Watson og Trott (1993) fant at 83% av pasienter med cervikogen hodepine hadde økt brystkyfose (>40 grader). En studie fra 2023 på migrenepasienter viste signifikant høyere kyfosevinkel (57 grader vs 38 grader) sammenlignet med friske kontroller. Hodepinen kommer ofte fra overbelastede nakkestrukturer som kompenserer for brystkrumningen.

 Armsmerter og nummenhet

 Stiv brystrygg kan påvirke skulderbladsposisjon og nervefunksjon. En studie fant at 78% av tilfeller med tennisalbue eller golfalbue hadde samtidig stiv brystrygg. Nummenhet og prikking i hendene kan skyldes kompresjon eller strekk av nerver i den kinetiske kjeden.

 Tretthet og nedsatt funksjon

 å holde kroppen oppreist mot en krum rygg krever konstant muskelarbeid. Mange opplever uforklarlig tretthet. Ved alvorlig kyfose kan lungefunksjonen påvirkes fordi brystkassen komprimeres. For mer om sammenhengen mellom pust og rygg, se pust, stress og rygg .

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Fibromyalgia with Chest Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is fibromyalgia?

 Fibromyalgia is a chronic condition characterized by widespread pain, severe
 fatigue and sleep disturbances. The condition affects approximately 2.7% of the global population, and
 women are affected more often than men at a ratio of 3:1.

 

 
 How common is chest pain in fibromyalgia?

 Chest pain is very common in fibromyalgia. One study found that 54% of
 fibromyalgia patients reported chest pain, compared to only 4% in the control group.
 Costochondritis-like symptoms occur in approximately 29%.

 

 
 What is the recommended treatment for fibromyalgia?

 According to EULAR guidelines from 2017, exercise is the a key treatment approach with a
 strong recommendation. Water exercise is well-documented short-term, while strength training is best
 long-term. Massage therapy over 5 weeks shows moderate effect.

 

 
 Can fibromyalgia get better?

 Fibromyalgia is chronic, but 66% experience improvement over time. Remission
 occurs in 17-47% after 1-2 years of active treatment. Regular exercise is the most important modifiable
 factor for better prognosis.

P: 1) Forsiktig myofascial behandling: ISDN-teknikk, lett massasje
   2) INGEN manipulasjon (osteoporose = absolutt kontraindikasjon for HVLA)
   3) INGEN brå bevegelser eller kraftig mobilisering
   4) Varmebehandling, gentle ROM-øvelser

   6) Fallforebygging: Vurder balanse og hjemmeforhold
   7) Oppfølging ukentlig i 3 uker, deretter behovsstyrt

Provide a structured clinical overview of Disc Herniation in the Lower Back.

Who is Affected by Disc Herniation?: Disc herniation typically affects adults between 30 and 50 years old, with approximately twice as many
 men as women (StatPearls, 2025). The lifetime risk for symptomatic herniation is 1-3% 
 (WFNS, 2024).

Causes and Risk Factors: From most to least common
Symptoms: The classic symptom is radicular pain - a sharp, burning or electric pain that radiates
 down the leg. The pain follows the nerve's distribution area and often extends below the knee.

Diagnosis: A thorough clinical examination is the foundation for diagnosis.

Spontaneous Resorption - The Herniation Can Resolve on Its Own: This is perhaps the most important information many patients don't receive: The body has a
 remarkable ability to resorb herniated disc material. Multiple meta-analyses confirm this.

Treatment: WFNS guidelines from 2024 recommend conservative treatment as first choice for most herniations. Surgery
 is considered only with failure of conservative treatment, severe motor deficit, or progressive
 neurological dysfunction.

Prognosis - What to Expect?: 85-90% of patients experience significant improvement within 6-12 weeks with
 conservative treatment.

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

4 Less Common Causes

 Some conditions are rarer but important to be aware of:

 
 Scheuermann's Disease

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounding) in the thoracic spine, usually discovered in adolescence.

 
 Abnormal rounding of the upper back

 Stiffness and aching pain

 Wedged vertebrae visible on X-ray

 Can be treated conservatively in most cases

 
 

 
 Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Rarer than in the neck and lower back, but can occur. Accounts for only 1-2% of all disc herniations.

 
 Often asymptomatic even when found on MRI

 Can cause radiation around the ribs

 Rarely requires surgery

 
 

 
 Ankylosing Spondylitis

 Rheumatic disease causing inflammation and gradual stiffening of the spine.

 
 Morning stiffness over 30 minutes

 Improves with activity

 Often onset before age 40

 Requires referral to rheumatologist

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Overpronasjon: Myte eller medisinsk faktum?.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er all pronasjon normalt?

 Ja, pronasjon er en helt naturlig bevegelse. Foten er designet for å pronere ved landing - det er kroppens innebygde støtdemping. Problemet oppstar når normal variasjon blir patologisert som overpronasjon. Det finnes ingen vitenskapelig definert grense for hva som er for mye pronasjon.

 

 
 Trenger barn med plattfot innleggssaler?

 Nei, i de aller fleste tilfeller. Helsebiblioteket (2022) konkluderer at det ikke finnes evidensgrunnlag for innleggssaler hos barn med plattfot. Fleksibel plattfot hos barn er en normalvariant som vanligvis utvikler seg normalt. Unødvendig behandling kan faktisk hindre naturlig fotutvikling.

 

 
 Hvorfor forskriver behandlere fortsatt for overpronasjon?

 Flere faktØrer spiller inn: tradisjon fra utdanning, Økonomiske insentiver (ortosemarkedet er verdt milliarder), visuell logikk (det ser feil ut), og manglende oppdatering på nyere forskning. Mange behandlere er genuint overbevist fordi de lærte dette som etablert vitenskap.

 

 
 Bør jeg slutte med bevegelseskontrollskoene mine?

 Hvis de er komfortable og du ikke har problemer, er det ingen grunn til å bytte umiddelbart. Men hvis du vurderer nye sko, tyder forskningen på at komfort er en bedre guide enn pronasjonsmåling. Gradvis overgang til mer nøytrale sko kan våre aktuelt for mange.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe med fotproblemer?

 Ja. Kiropraktorer vurderer hele bevegelsesapparatet og kan identifisere om fotplagene skyldes lokal...

Forklar prognose for Smerter mellom skulderbladene.

Prognose

 Utsiktene for de fleste med smerter mellom skulderbladene er gode. Knecht og kollegaer (BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders, 2020) fulgte 90 pasienter med brystkassesmerter gjennom ett år og fant at 80% hadde et gunstig forløp med rask bedring innen første måned.

 Tilbakefall er vanlig

 Samtidig viser forskning at tilbakefall er vanlig. Studier på ryggsmerter generelt viser at 24–80% opplever minst ett tilbakefall innen 12 måneder (da Silva, Journal of Physiotherapy, 2019). Tidligere episoder øker risikoen for nye å har du hatt mer enn to episoder, tredobles sjansen for tilbakefall.

 Den viktigste enkeltfaktoren for prognosen er hvor lenge du har hatt plagene. Smerte som har vart mer enn tre måneder ved behandlingsstart gir betydelig dårligere utsikter. Dette understreker verdien av tidlig intervensjon.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Should I stretch my hamstrings?

 NO - this is a common mistake. Stretching compresses the tendon against the sit
 bone and often makes things worse. Focus on strength training instead. Gentle dynamic mobility is fine,
 but avoid prolonged static stretching.

 

 
 Can I continue running?

 Often you need to significantly reduce volume initially. Flat running at low
 intensity is tolerated better than hills and intervals. Build up gradually as pain subsides. Running
 should not cause more than 3/10 pain.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 PHT is often long-lasting. Expect 3-6 months of proper treatment for significant
 improvement. Some need up to 12 months. Early diagnosis and treatment give better prognosis. Patience is
 key.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Cortisone injection can provide short-term pain relief, but is not first choice.
 Research shows it does not improve long-term outcomes and can weaken tendon tissue. Strength training is
 more effective for lasting improvement.

 

 
 How should I sit?

 Avoid hard chairs. Use a seat cushion that relieves the sit bone - either a
 wedge-shaped cushion or one with a cutout at the back. Get up and move regularly. Consider a standing
 desk for periods.

Behandling ved C5-C6 prolaps

 Behandlingen av C5-C6 prolaps er i de aller fleste tilfeller konservativ (ikke-kirurgisk). Målet er å redusere smerte, bevare funksjon og støtte kroppens naturlige helingsprosess.

Explain treatment for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

Treatment

 How Can the Chiropractor Help?

 Neck-Related Headache (Cervicogenic Headache)

 Many people with headache and facial pain have a component from the neck. Cervicogenic headache arises from joints, muscles, or nerves in the upper neck and can cause pain radiating toward the eye, temple, or forehead.

 For this type of headache, there is moderate evidence that manual treatment such as mobilization and manipulation can reduce pain intensity, attack frequency, and disability.

 For Migraine

 For migraine, the evidence for manual treatment is more uncertain. This doesn't mean treatment is useless - many experience relief, and neck treatment may be relevant if neck problems contribute to the migraine picture. But expectations should be realistic.

 What Do We Do in Practice?

 During consultation, we conduct a thorough examination to map
 Headache type (migraine, tension headache , cervicogenic, or mixed forms)

 Neck and jaw joint function

 Muscular trigger points 

 Need for referral to a doctor

 Treatment is tailored to findings and may include joint mobilization, soft tissue treatment, dry needling, and exercises.

Describe symptoms - more than just back pain for Flat Back.

Symptoms - More Than Just Back Pain

 What makes hypokyphosis and especially Straight Back Syndrome challenging are the symptoms that can be
 confused with heart disease.

 A classic study by Davies et al. (Quarterly Journal of Medicine, 1980) documented the symptom profile
 Palpitations: 38% of patients (most common symptom)

 Chest pain: 29%

 Breathing difficulty: 19%

 Chest pain and "heart anxiety"

 When the chest cavity lacks the normal curvature, space is reduced. The heart can be pressed against the
 sternum, and this can cause pain resembling angina (heart cramp). In some cases, ECG may show changes
 resembling a heart attack, even when the heart is healthy (Shiba & Kenzaka, Internal Medicine Case Reports
 Journal, 2022).

 Connection with heart valve problems

 A striking finding is that 58-67% of patients with Straight Back Syndrome have concurrent mitral valve
 prolapse (Davies, 1980; Ansari, Clinical Cardiology, 1985). Of these, a significant proportion (77% in one
 series) later require heart surgery.

 Breathing problems

 A flat thoracic spine reduces chest mobility. The ribs need the curvature to rotate optimally during
 inhalation, and problems here can resemble rib lock . Lung function tests may
 show reduced capacity - one case report documented over 2 liters improvement in lung capacity after
 treatment that increased the kyphosis angle by 10 degrees (PMC, 2017). Read more about the connection
 between breathing, stress and back .

 Musculoskeletal symptoms

 Pain between the shoulder blades is common. The shoulder
 blades lack their natural "shelf" on the ribcage when the curve is flat. A study found that hypokyphosis
 increased the risk of shoulder impingement (OR 2.14) (LOHAS study, 2014).

Differential diagnoses for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck?

Spondylosis and foraminal stenosis (68-75%)

 Age-related changes gradually lead to narrowing of the opening where the nerve passes. Dominant cause
 in people over 50.

Disc herniation (20-25%)

 Acute bulging of the intervertebral disc pressing on the nerve root. Most common in younger patients
 in their 20s-40s.

Injury/trauma (~15%)

 Whiplash -type injuries or other neck trauma.

Myofascial trigger points

 Active trigger points in the upper trapezius occur in 30-40% of patients with chronic neck pain . Causes radiation that can mimic radiculopathy.

Explain exercise 2: toe spreading for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 2: Toe Spreading

 After years in narrow shoes, many have lost the ability to actively spread their toes. Toe spreading reactivates the abductor muscles and improves forefoot stability.

 How to Perform Toe Spreading

 Starting position: Sit or stand with your foot flat on the floor

 Movement: Spread the toes as far apart as possible

 Focus: Especially try to spread the big toe away from the others

 Hold: 5-10 seconds

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps

 Sets: 2-3 sets per foot

 Tip: Use Toe Spacers

 If you struggle to spread your toes, toe spacers can help. Use them passively while sitting or sleeping to gradually regain toe mobility. Start with 15-30 minutes and increase gradually.

Explain prognosis - what can you expect? for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?

 Here's the good news: the prognosis for sciatica is generally good, but it often takes longer than many
 think.

 The positive
 The majority improve without surgery

 50% experience significant improvement within 4 weeks

 55-70% have recovered within a year

 Disc herniations can shrink and be reabsorbed over time

 The realistic
 Median time to improvement is 10-12 weeks - not 6 weeks

 20-30% have persistent symptoms after 1-2 years

 Recurrence affects about 1 in 4 within a few years

Beskriv Vektløfterskulder (Distal clavicular osteolysis) i kontekst av AC-ledd-artrose: Alt du trenger å vite.

Tidligere skade

 

 En AC-leddsforskyvning (AC-ledd separasjon) eller kragebeinbrudd Øker risikoen for senere artrose i leddet.

 

 Vektløfterskulder (Distal clavicular osteolysis)

 
 Spesiell tilstand hos styrketrenende

 Vektløfterskulder er en tilstand der enden av kragebenet brytes ned på grunn av repeterende mikrotraumer. Vanlig hos de som trener tungt benkpress, skulderpress og dips.

 
 Smerte på toppen av skulderen

 Forverres ved tungt løft

 Røntgen viser oppløsning av den ytre enden av kragebenet

 93% blir bedre med aktivitetsmodifisering

 
 

 Risikofaktorer

 
 Alder over 40 Ør

 Tungt fysisk arbeid eller styrketrening

 Tidligere AC-leddskade

 Overhead-idretter

 Tidligere brudd i kragebein eller skulder

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptomer

 

 Symptomene ved AC-ledd-artrose er ofte karakteristiske og lokalisert:

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Lokalisert smerte: Pa toppen av skulderen, ofte pekbar

 Provokasjon ved kroppsbevegelser: Ta handen over til motsatt skulder (cross-body)

 Smerte ved overhead: Særlig i enden av bevegelsen

 Krepitasjon: Knirking eller klikking fra leddet

 Nattesmerte: Ved å ligge på affisert side - les mer om søvn og skuldersmerter

 

 
 Aktiviteter som typisk provoserer

 
 Benkpress og skulderpress

 Dips og push-ups

 Ta på seg jakke

 Rekke opp i skap

 Sove på affisert side

 
 

 Skille fra andre tilstander

 AC-ledd-smerte kan ligne på andre skuldertilstander, men har noen saertrekk:

 
 Tegn som peker mot AC-leddet

 
 Smerte lokalisert helt på toppen av skulderen

 Positiv cross-body adduction test

 Omhet ved direkte palpasjon over AC-leddet

 Smerte i enden av overhead-bevegelse

 Smertelindring ved injeksjon i AC-leddet

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Svake fåtter: RotÅrsaken de fleste overser.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det å styrke fåttene?

 Merkbare forbedringer ses typisk etter 4-8 uker med konsekvent trening. Liverpool-studien viste 57% styrkeØkning etter 6 måneder med minimalistsko. Fottrening bør ses som vedlikehold - akkurat som annen trening.

 

 
 Er barfotgåing trygt?

 For de fleste er gradvis barfotgåing trygt og gunstig. Start innendØrs på myke underlag, og Øk gradvis. Personer med diabetes, nevropati eller nedsatt følelse i fåttene bør våre forsiktige og konsultere helsepersonell først.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene fåttene selv om jeg har plattfot?

 Ja, absolutt. Forskning (Huang 2022 meta-analyse) viser at fottrening kan Øke buestyrken og forbedre funksjon selv hos personer med flate fåtter. Fleksibel plattfot responderer ofte godt på styrketrening.

 

 
 Bør jeg kaste innleggssålene mine?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Hvis du har diabetes, alvorlige deformiteter eller spesifikke medisinske indikasjoner, kan ortoser fortsatt våre viktige. For uspesifikke plager kan gradvis nedtrapping kombinert med fottrening våre et godt alternativ. Diskuter med en fagperson.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe med svake fåtter?

 Ja. Kiropraktorer vurderer hele bevegelsesapparatet og kan identifisere om fotplagene skyldes lokale forhold eller kompensasjoner fra hofter, bekken eller rygg. Behandlingen inkluderer ofte leddmobilisering, bløtvevsarbeid og veiledning i målrettet fottrening.

Describe treatment options for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 85% recover with simple measures targeting the triggering cause.

 
 First measures:

 
 Avoid tight pants and belts

 Weight loss if overweight

 Avoid prolonged standing

 Remove heavy tool belts

 Adjust car seat and seat belt

 
 

 For persistent symptoms

 
 Nerve mobilization - gentle exercises to "free" the nerve

 Soft tissue treatment - around the inguinal ligament and hip flexors

 Hip flexor stretching - reduces tension on the nerve

 Medications - painkillers or neuropathic agents

 

 During pregnancy

 Meralgia paresthetica in pregnancy often resolves after delivery. Measures:

 
 Avoid standing too long

 Use support belt high (not on the hip bone)

 Rest with slightly bent hips

 Symptoms usually disappear after delivery

 

 Injection treatment

 For persistent symptoms, injection with local anesthetic and cortisone can provide relief. This can be
 both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 Surgery

 Considered only when conservative treatment over several months has not helped. Options:

 
 Neurolysis - freeing the nerve from surrounding tissue

 Neurectomy - cutting the nerve (results in permanent numbness)

Assess red flags: 48-year-old female with symmetric swelling and pain in MCP joints (2nd-4th finger bilaterally) and PIP joints for 8 weeks. Morning stiffness 50 minutes. Fatigue. No previous joint problems.

URGENCY: REFER ROUTINE (within 2-4 weeks)

Suspected rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Clinical reasoning:
- Symmetric polyarthritis in MCP/PIP joints = classic for RA
- Morning stiffness >30 min = inflammatory pattern (mechanical: <30 min)
- Fatigue = systemic inflammation
- Onset age 48 = typical for RA (40-60 years)
- No acute danger, but EARLY treatment (within 3 months) gives significantly better long-term prognosis
- "Window of opportunity" = first 3-6 months are critical to prevent joint erosion

ACTION: Blood work (anti-CCP, RF, CRP, ESR, CBC). Rheumatology referral within 2-4 weeks. Chiropractic treatment of neck/back can continue. Do NOT manipulate swollen joints directly.

Årsaker til svimmelhet - fra vanligst til sjeldnest

 

 Her er de viktigste Årsakene, sortert etter hvor ofte de forekommer:

 
 
 Krystallsyke (BPPV)

 17-42% av tilfellene
 

 Gå til full artikkel om krystallsyke (BPPV) →

 Krystallsyke er den vanligste Årsaken til svimmelhet som utredes i klinikker (Bosner, BMC Fam Pract, 2018). Tilstanden oppstar når små kalsiumkrystaller løsner fra sin plass i balanseorganet og havner i buegangene.

 Kjennetegn:

 
 Korte, intense spinnanfall (10-60 sekunder)

 Utløses av bestemte hodebevegelser - snu seg i sengen, se opp, bøye seg ned

 Kvalme under anfallene

 Symptomfri mellom anfallene

 
 

 
 
 Vestibular migrene

 ca. 1-3% av befolkningen
 

 Gå til full artikkel om vestibular migrene →

 Livstidsprevalens på rundt 1%, men nyere amerikanske data antyder opptil 2,7% (Formeister, Otol Neurotol, 2018). Barany Society har identifisert dette som "den desidert vanligste Årsaken" til kombinerte nakkesmerter og Vestibulære symptomer. Kan forekomme med eller uten hodepine.

 

 
 
 Vestibularisnevritt

 3-10% i svimmelhetsklinikker

Differensialdiagnoser ved Kne?

Overbelastning (vanligste årsak)

 Overbelastningsskader oppstår når vevet utsettes for mer repetitiv belastning enn det tåler. Typiske eksempler: løperkne, hopperkne, IT-bénd syndrom og beinhinnebetennelse. Rask økning i treningsmengde er en gjennomgående risikofaktor.

Slitasje (degenerative forandringer)

 Med alderen får mange naturlige aldersforandringer i kne og menisker. De fleste degenerative meniskfunn på MR gir ingen symptomer. Kneartrose utvikler seg gradvis over ør og gir økende smerter, stivhet og redusert bevegelighet.

Akutte skader

 Korsbéndskader, akutte meniskskader og muskelstrekk oppstår typisk ved plutselige bevegelser, fall eller direkte treff. Disse krever ofte en annen tilnærming enn overbelastningsskader.

Why Is This So Difficult?

 

 
 
 44%
 of hip patients are initially given the wrong
 diagnosis
 

 

 Back, hip and sciatica share overlapping symptoms and pain patterns. Leg pain can come
 from the hip joint, from the back via the nerves, or from both places simultaneously.
 Research shows that almost half of all patients with hip problems are first given a
 wrong diagnosis - often treated for back problems they don't have.

 This article helps you understand the most important differences and why a thorough
 examination is so important.

Describe causes and risk factors for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Causes are ranked from most to least common
 1. Degenerative Changes (Most Common)

 The most common underlying cause. Disc material loses water content and elasticity over time.

 2. Trauma

 37-49% of patients have previous injury such as fall, car accident, or sports mishap (StatPearls,
 2024).

 3. Scheuermann's Disease

 Juvenile kyphosis with altered spinal morphology increases risk (P<0.01) (EFORT Open Reviews, 2021).
 Read more about Scheuermann's disease .

 4. Smoking

 Associated with 18% reduction in disc height over time (EFORT Open Reviews, 2021).

 5. Repetitive Rotational Loading

 Sports like golf, softball, and baseball with repeated twisting.

 Approximately 75% of thoracic herniations occur below the T8 level , with T11-T12 being
 the most common location, followed by T7-T8 (21.8%) and T8-T9 (15%) (Sarsilmaz et al., 2018).

Bilateral beinsmerte og stivhet etter lang gange, bedring ved hvile og forover-bøyning. Koder?

L86 — Lumbalt ryggsyndrom med utstråling

Bilateral beinsmerte forverret av gange og bedret av forover-bøyning er klassisk nevrogen claudicatio ved lumbal spinal stenose.

Differensier fra vaskulær claudicatio:
- Nevrogen (L86): Bedres ved sitting/forover-bøyning, bilateral, dermatomal
- Vaskulær (K92): Bedres ved stående hvile, distalt-proksimalt, svake pulser

Feil: Å kode K92 (Perifere karsykdommer) når det er nevrogen claudicatio.

Plantar fascitt. ICPC-2 kode?

L98 — Ervervet deformitet av ekstremitet

Plantar fascitt kodes L98 i ICPC-2. NB: ICD-10 koden M72.2 brukes IKKE. I ICPC-2 brukes L98 for plantar fascitt.

Explain Cortisone Injection in Shoulder: Friend or Foe? to a patient.

"You just need a cortisone injection, then it'll be fine." Many people with shoulder pain have heard this. Cortisone injections are
 one of the most common treatments for shoulder problems, and for some they can be a valuable part of
 treatment.

 But research in recent years has significantly nuanced the picture. We now know more about both the
 benefits and drawbacks - and when cortisone is actually the right choice versus when other approaches
 may be better.

 In this article, you'll get a balanced overview of what cortisone does, when it can
 help, what risks exist, and what alternatives you should consider.

Explain prognosis for Meniere's Disease.

Prognosis

 57% 
 full control within 2 years 

 71% 
 full control within 8 years 

 35-47% 
 bilateral involvement 

 Spontaneous improvement: 57% achieve full control of vertigo within 2 years, and 71% within 8 years - without surgical treatment

 Hearing loss: Most develop permanent hearing loss of 50-60 dB over 5-10 years. Total deafness is uncommon

 Bilateral involvement: The risk of the other ear being affected increases - up to 35% within 10 years and 47% within 20 years

 In some cases, the chronic dizziness can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness) , which requires a different treatment approach.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Temple Headache.

Causes and Risk Factors: Tension headache is the most frequent cause of temple pain. The pain is typically described as a pressing band around the head, often bilateral. It peaks in the 30-39 age range and is somewhat more common in women.

Symptoms: Symptoms of temple headache vary depending on the underlying cause
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of temple headache is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. The chiropractor will map the pain's character, duration, triggering factors and any accompanying symptoms.

Red Flags - when you should see a doctor: Temporal arteritis can cause permanent vision loss in up to 20% of untreated patients. Scandinavia has the world's highest prevalence.

Treatment: Treatment approach depends on the underlying cause. Early treatment can often provide faster improvement than waiting.

Prognosis: Prognosis for temple headache is generally good, but varies depending on cause and duration.

Describe diagnosis for Shoulder Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is made based on medical history, clinical examination and imaging.

 Clinical examination

 Reduced active and passive range of motion

 Crepitation during movement

 Pain when loading the joint

 Muscle atrophy may be seen in long-standing cases

 Imaging

 X-ray

 First choice. Shows classic osteoarthritis signs
 Narrowed joint space

 Bone spurs (osteophytes)

 Subchondral sclerosis

 Subchondral cysts

 MRI

 Useful for assessing
 The condition of the rotator cuff

 Cartilage status

 Ruling out other conditions

 Imaging findings do not equal symptoms

 Many have significant degenerative changes on imaging without symptoms. The degree of wear on X-ray
 correlates poorly with pain level. Treatment is based on symptoms, not images.

Identify red flags for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis):

IMPORTANT WARNING

 Treatment of hypokyphosis is NOT the same as treatment of common back pain or rounded back.

Describe treatment options for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

Hvordan diagnostiseres Horisontal Kanal BPPV?

Diagnostikk

 

 Supine roll-test (gullstandarden)

 Pasienten ligger på ryggen med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hodet dreies raskt 90 grader til en side og holdes i 30-60 sekunder mens Øyebevegelser observeres. Deretter gjentas testen til motsatt side. Testens sensitivitet er rapportert til 89,5% (Barany Society Guidelines).

 
 Ved geotropisk variant

 Øynene slær mot bakken på begge sider, men sterkest på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Ved apogeotropisk variant

 Øynene slær bort fra bakken, og den svakeste responsen er på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Viktig rekkefølge

 Supine roll-testen bør ideelt utføres får Dix-Hallpike-testen, da Dix-Hallpike kan flytte krystaller og påvirke resultatene.

 

 
 Røde flagg - kontakt lege umiddelbart ved:

 
 Svimmelhet som varer kontinuerlig over 2 minutter (BPPV gir korte anfall)

 Plutselig hØrselstap eller kraftig Øresus

 Dobbeltsyn eller andre synsforstyrrelser

 Kraftig hodepine ulikt tidligere opplevd

 Ansiktslammelse, nummenhet eller taleforstyrrelser

 Koordinasjonsproblemer eller ustå gange

Identifiser røde flagg for Korsryggsmerter.

Hekseskudd (akutt lumbago)

 Gå til full artikkel om hekseskudd ? 

 Hekseskudd er en plutselig, intens smerte i korsryggen som gjør det vanskelig å rette seg opp. Ved et hekseskudd oppstår vanligvis en akutt muskelspasme eller leddløsning.

 Vanlige utløsende faktorer

 Løft med vridning å særlig tunge gjenstander

 Plutselige bevegelser eller snubletrinn

 Langvarig stillesitting etterfulgt av rask bevegelse

 Ingen klar årsak (opptil 50% av tilfellene)

 Symptomer på hekseskudd

 Plutselig, intens smerte å ofte beskrevet som å løsningå eller øknivstikkå

 Uttalt stivhet å vanskelig å rette seg opp, bøye seg eller rotere

 Muskelspasmer du kan kjenne som harde øknuterå

 Smertelette i hvile å ofte i fosterstilling

 Hekseskudd vs. isjias

 Ved hekseskudd holder smerten seg i ryggen å den stråler ikke ned i bena. Utstråling under kneet, prikking eller nummenhet kan tyde på isjias.

 Prognose: De fleste opplever betydelig bedring innen 1–2 uker. Omtrent 70% er vesentlig bedre innen én uke. Med riktig behandling kan mange oppleve smertelindring allerede etter første time.

Differential diagnoses for Posterior Canal BPPV: When the World Spins Backwards?

Idiopathic (50-83%)

Head Injury and Trauma (10-20%)

Vestibular Migraine (5-15%)

 Patients with migraine have increased risk for BPPV.

Inner Ear Diseases (2-5%)

 Meniere's disease , vestibular neuritis , labyrinthitis.

SR (senkning) og CRP

 Senkningen (SR) er typisk betydelig forhøyet, ofte over 50 mm/t og ikke sjelden over 100 mm/t. CRP er også forhøyet. Disse markørene er sensitive, men ikke spesifikke - de kan være forhøyet ved mange tilstander. I sjeldne tilfeller (ca. 5%) kan SR og CRP være normale tross aktiv GCA.

Temporal arteriebiopsi (gullstandard)

 En liten vevsprøve fra tinningarterien undersøkes under mikroskop. Sensitiviteten er 80-90% (ACR/EULAR 2022). Biopsi kan være falsk negativ dersom betennelsen er flekkvis (segmental) og prøven tas fra et uaffisert område. Biopsien gjøres under lokalbedøvelse og er et relativt ukomplisert inngrep.

Ultralyd av tinningarterien

 Fargedoppler-ultralyd kan vise et karakteristisk halo-tegn - en mørk ring rundt arterien som representerer ødem i arterieveggen (Luqmani et al.). Ultralyd er et non-invasivt alternativ til biopsi og er raskt tilgjengelig, men krever erfaren undersøker.

ACR/EULAR 2022 klassifikasjonskriterier

 De oppdaterte kriteriene fra 2022 bruker et poengsystem basert på kliniske funn, blodprøver og bildediagnostikk. Viktige elementer inkluderer alder over 50, nyoppstått hodepine, forhøyet SR/CRP, temporal arterie-abnormaliteter, og positiv biopsi eller bildediagnostikk.

Explain treatment for Headache and Dizziness.

Treatment

 For Cervicogenic Dizziness (moderate evidence)

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A systematic review of 4 randomized studies shows that manual treatment is effective for neck-related dizziness. Studies showed significant improvement in dizziness intensity and frequency that persisted at 12-month follow-up.

 Specific neck techniques targeting the upper cervical spine

 Trigger point treatment of SCM and suboccipital muscles

 Mobilization of stiff neck joints

 Exercises to normalize proprioceptive function

 For Vestibular Migraine (limited evidence)

 There are only case reports and small case series on manual treatment for vestibular migraine . However, many patients have a neck component that can be addressed. Medication prophylaxis may be relevant in collaboration with a doctor.

 For BPPV (strong evidence)

 Repositioning Maneuvers

 BPPV is treated with specific repositioning maneuvers - most often the Epley maneuver . Most people become symptom-free after 1-3 treatments.

 Treatment Course

 Cervicogenic dizziness: Typically 2-6 treatments over 6 weeks

 BPPV: Often 1-3 treatments

 Vestibular migraine: Requires multidisciplinary approach

Explain treatment for Thumb Arthritis (CMC.

Treatment

 Conservative treatment is first choice

 Most people get good relief without surgery

 Hand exercises and strengthening of stabilizing muscles

 Thumb splint for relief

 Activity modification

 Treatment plan

 1. Splinting

 Thumb splint stabilizes the joint and reduces load. Can be used as needed or continuously.

 2. Hand exercises

 Strengthening exercises for thumb stabilizing muscles. Increases stability and reduces pain.

 3. Activity modification

 Ergonomic aids, changing grip technique, and break strategies.

 4. Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of overloaded musculature, gentle mobilization. Treatment of trigger points in thumb muscles can also be helpful.

 Cortisone for thumb arthritis

 Unlike some other conditions, cortisone has limited effect for thumb arthritis. The
 effect is often short-lived (2-3 weeks), and repeated injections are not recommended. Hand exercises
 provide better long-term results.

Explain evidence-based treatment for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Evidence-based treatment

 AAOS (American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons) updated their guidelines in 2024. Here's what the
 research shows
 First choice: Night splint

 50-70% experience improvement with nightly use of wrist splint (Page et al., 2012)

 Keeps the wrist in neutral position during sleep

 Significantly reduces night symptoms

 Recommended as first-line treatment (AAOS 2024)

 Manual therapy matches surgery short-term

 An important study (Fernandez-de-las-Penas et al.) showed that manual treatment gave equally
 good results as surgery at 1 and 3 month follow-up. This included
 Nerve gliding exercises

 Myofascial release of forearm and hand

 Mobilization of wrist bones

 Treatment plan at . Night splint (first choice)

 Guidance on proper use of wrist splint. Must be used every night for at least 3-4 weeks to evaluate
 effect.

 2. Nerve gliding exercises

 Structured exercises that mobilize the median nerve through its path, to reduce adhesions and improve
 nerve mobility.

 3. Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of forearm, mobilization of wrist bones, and nerve gliding techniques.

 4. Ergonomic guidance

 Assessment of workstation, mouse use and keyboard height. Small changes can make a big difference.

 When is surgery considered?

 No effect from conservative treatment after 3-6 months

 Severe symptoms with constant numbness

 Visible muscle wasting (thenar atrophy)

 Significantly reduced nerve function on neurography

 Surgical treatment (carpal tunnel release) has very high success rate (>90%), but most don't need it with
 proper conservative treatment.

Forklar behandling — trening vs. kirurgi for Rotator Cuff — Komplett Guide til Rotatorkuffen.

Behandling — trening vs. kirurgi

 Forskningen pa rotator cuff-behandling har endret seg dramatisk de siste 10-15 arene. Norge har vart i frontlinjen av denne utviklingen. 

 Trening som forstevalg

 For degenerative (atraumatiske) rotator cuff-skader — som utgjor det store flertallet — er strukturert trening forstevalg. Flere hoykvaltietsstudier stotter dette
 Norsk forskning: Moosmayer et al.

 Stefan Moosmayer og kolleger ved Oslo og Lovisenberg gjennomforte en randomisert kontrollert studie som sammenlignet trening med kirurgi for sma og mellomstore rotator cuff-rupturer. Resultatene etter 1 ar viste ingen signifikant forskjell mellom gruppene (Kukkonen et al., 2015, Bone Joint J).

 Enda mer imponerende: ved 10 ars oppfolging (Moosmayer et al., 2019) var det fortsatt ingen klinisk betydningsfull forskjell. Treningsgruppen klarte seg like bra som kirurgigruppen pa lang sikt.

 OPTIROT-studien (pagaende)

 OPTIROT er en stor norsk randomisert studie som sammenligner trening med kirurgi for sma og mellomstore rupturer. Studien ledes fra Oslo og Lovisenberg og er en av de viktigste pagaende studiene pa feltet internasjonalt.

 Re-tear etter kirurgi: 20-40%

 Et viktig poeng som ofte underkommuniseres: 20-40% av opererte rotator cuff-rupturer ryker igjen (Carr et al., 2015, Lancet). For store og massive rupturer er re-tear-raten enda hoyere. Interessant nok har mange pasienter god funksjon til tross for re-ruptur — noe som reiser sporsmalet om det er selve rehabiliteringen, snarere enn senetilhelingen, som gir resultater.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Skulder Impingement?

Overbelastning og repetitive bevegelser

 Vanligst 

 Gjentatte bevegelser med armen over hodet er den hyppigste utløsende faktoren. Dette gjelder både yrker (maler, elektriker, rørlegger) og idretter (svømming, tennis, håndball, volleyball).

Muskulær ubalanse

 Svakhet i rotatormansjetten og scapulastabilisatorene (musklene som styrer skulderbladet) gjør at overarmsbenet vandrer oppover og innsnevrer det subakromiale rommet. Dette er en av de viktigste modifiserbare risikofaktorene.

Holdningsrelaterte faktorer

Other Common Conditions

 

 
 
 Metatarsalgia (Forefoot Pain)

 5-36% prevalence
 

 Go to full article on metatarsalgia

 Collective term for pain in the forefoot. Accounts for 85% of all foot pain in middle-aged women.

 Most common causes: Mechanical overload (most common), wrong footwear (high heels shift 70-80% of weight to forefoot), foot deformities like hallux valgus (5.4x increased risk), high arch.

 Prognosis: 80-85% improve with conservative treatment within 6-8 weeks.

 

 
 
 Hallux Valgus ("Bunion")

 19% prevalence
 

 Go to full article on hallux valgus

 spreaders, strength exercises for foot muscles. Surgery is only considered with significant pain and
 functional impairment.

 times more often. Accounts for approx. 40% of metatarsalgia diagnoses.

 months. Cortisone injections if conservative treatment doesn't help (82% satisfied). Surgery as last resort.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Spondylolistese: Glidning av virvler?

1. Istmisk spondylolistese

 Vanligst 

 Skyldes en defekt eller brudd i pars interarticularis (spondylolysis). Vanligst hos unge idrettsutøvere, særlig i idretter med mye ekstensjon og rotasjon som turn, bryting og vektløfting.

2. Degenerativ spondylolistese

 Vanligst hos eldre 

 Oppstar på grunn av aldersrelatert slitasje i fasettledd og mellomvirvelskiver. Vanligst hos personer over 50 år, særlig kvinner, og forekommer typisk på L4-L5 nivå.

3. Dysplastisk (medfådt) spondylolistese

 Skyldes en medfådt misdannelse i virvelen som gir ustabilitet. Oppdages ofte i barndom eller ungdom.

4. Traumatisk spondylolistese

 Oppstar etter akutt skade eller brudd i virvelen. Kan skyldes ulykker, fall eller idrettsskader.

5. Patologisk spondylolistese

 Skyldes sykdom som svekker benvevet, for eksempel osteoporose, infeksjon eller tumor.

Describe How to Distinguish Between the Conditions for Numbness in Fingers: Is It the Neck or the Hand?.

How to Distinguish Between the Conditions

 

 
 Points toward carpal tunnel:

 
 Do you wake up at night with numbness in your fingers?

 Does shaking your hand help?

 Do symptoms worsen with repetitive hand work?

 Is the little finger completely free of symptoms?

 
 

 
 Points toward the neck:

 
 Do you have pain or stiffness in your neck?

 Do symptoms worsen with certain neck positions?

 Does pain radiate down the arm?

 Does raising your arm overhead help?

 
 

 When both conditions are present - double crush

 In some cases, the patient actually has both conditions simultaneously. This is called "double crush syndrome", where irritation of the nerve at one level makes it more vulnerable to effects elsewhere.

 Prevalence varies from 14-26% depending on study design (Upton & McComas, 1973; subsequent studies). Practically, this means thorough examination of both neck and wrist is important in all patients with finger numbness.

Describe diagnosis for Kyphosis and Poor Posture.

Diagnosis

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination is often more important than imaging. The chiropractor assesses posture
 from the side, checks if the curve straightens when you lie flat (flexibility test), tests neck and
 shoulder mobility, and examines muscle strength and balance.

 Wall Test

 A simple wall test can reveal forward head posture: stand with your heels against the wall and measure
 the distance from the back of your head to the wall.

 When is Imaging Necessary?

 X-ray or MRI is rarely necessary with typical functional kyphosis. Imaging may be appropriate if
 structural cause is suspected (rigid curve), after trauma, if osteoporosis or fracture is suspected, or
 with neurological symptoms. Remember that many findings on imaging, such as age-related changes, don't
 necessarily explain your symptoms.

Klinisk oppsummering av Thorakalt diskusprolaps.

Kort oppsummert

 Hva det er: Prolaps (brokk) av mellomvirvelskive i brystryggen som kan presse på nerver eller ryggmarg.

 Forekomst: Kun 0,25-0,75 % av alle symptomatiske diskusprolapser - svært sjeldent (StatPearls, 2024).

 Vanligste årsaker: Degenerative forandringer (slitasje), tidligere traume, Scheuermanns sykdom.

 Kiropraktisk behandling: Begrenset rolle - primært differensialdiagnostikk og henvisning. Ingen RCT-er for manuell behandling av thorakalt prolaps.

 Røde flagg: Svakhet i begge ben, blåre-/tarmforstyrrelser, gangvansker, raskt progredierende symptomer.

Explain Fibromyalgia with Chest Pain to a patient.

Fibromyalgia is a chronic condition characterized by widespread pain, severe fatigue and sleep
 disturbances. The condition affects approximately 2.7% of the global population (Heidari et al.,
 Rheumatology International, 2017). Fibromyalgia is one of several conditions that can cause pain in the thoracic spine and chest region .

 Women are affected more often than men, at a ratio of approximately 3:1 when modern diagnostic criteria
 are used (ACR 2016). Typical onset is in the 40s-50s, and women receive the diagnosis on average 9 years
 earlier than men.

Describe What is stress neck? for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

What is stress neck?

 

 Stress neck describes a condition where psychological stress manifests as physical tension in the neck
 and shoulder muscles. When we experience stress, the body activates the "fight-or-flight" response which
 increases muscle tension - especially in the neck, shoulders and jaw.

 
 The Stress-Tension-Pain Cycle

 Many get caught in a vicious cycle:

 
 Stress - increased muscle tension

 Tension - trigger points and pain

 Pain - more stress and worry

 More stress - even more tension

 
 Treatment often needs to address multiple links in this cycle for lasting improvement.

 

 What are trigger points?

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle tissue that feel like hard knots when palpated. They
 have two important characteristics:

 
 Local tenderness: The point is painful when pressed

 Referred pain: Pressing the point can trigger pain in other areas - e.g., trigger
 points in the trapezius can cause headache

How is When Dizziness Doesn't Fit: Is It BPPV or Something Else? diagnosed?

Why Duration is Key to Diagnosis

 

 The simplest way to distinguish between different causes of dizziness is to ask: How long do the episodes last?

 
 Seconds (under one minute)

 Classic BPPV. Crystals in the ear trigger brief, intense dizziness with head movements.

 

 
 Minutes to hours (5 min - 72 hours)

 Vestibular migraine. About 30% have attacks lasting minutes, 30% hours, and 30% several days.

 

 
 20 minutes to 12 hours

 Meniere's disease. Attacks come with hearing loss, tinnitus, and pressure sensation in the ear.

 

 
 Days to weeks (constant)

 Vestibular neuritis. Acute inflammation of the balance nerve causes persistent dizziness that gradually subsides.

 

 
 Months (persistent daily)

 PPPD. Chronic unsteadiness worsened by movement and visual stimuli.

 

 
 Important rule

 If your dizziness lasts longer than one minute per episode, it's probably not classic BPPV.

Describe Variation and Breaks for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Variation and Breaks

 

 No matter how perfect the ergonomics are, the body is not made for prolonged stillness. Variation and
 breaks are more important than the "perfect" setup:

 
 Break structure

 
 Micro-breaks (30 sec - 1 min): Every 20-30 minutes. Straighten up, roll
 shoulders, look away from the screen.

 Short breaks (5-10 min): Every hour. Stand up, walk a few steps, stretch.

 Longer breaks (15-30 min): Lunch etc. Get away from the workstation completely.
 

 
 

 
 Sit-stand desk

 A sit-stand desk allows you to alternate between sitting and standing work. It's not about standing
 all day (that's not good either), but about variation.

 
 Start with short standing periods (15-30 min)

 Alternate between sitting and standing several times a day

 Remember that ergonomics must also be correct in standing position

 
 

 
 Tips to remember breaks

 
 Use app or timer to remind you of breaks

 Drink plenty of water - then you also have to get up more often

 Place the printer, coffee machine etc. so you have to walk

 Take phone calls standing or walking

Beskriv symptomer for Cervikal Foraminal Stenose.

Symptomer

 Typiske symptomer

 Radikular smerte: Skarp, brennende eller elektrisk smerte som stråler fra nakke til arm

 Nummenhet og prikking: Ofte i spesifikke fingre avhengig av hvilken nerve som er påvirket

 Svakhet: Redusert kraft i spesifikke muskler i arm eller hand

 Nakkestivhet: Spesielt ved bevegelser som lukker foramen (ekstensjon + rotasjon til smertefull side)

 Spurlings test

 En klassisk test for foraminal stenose: Hodet bøyes bakover og roteres mot smertefull side, deretter trykkes lett ned. Positiv test reproduserer utstråling til armen. Dette "lukker" foramen og provoserer symptomene.

 Symptomfordeling etter niva

 C5-nerven (C4-C5 stenose)

 Smerte: Skulder og overarm

 Svakhet: Skulderløft, albuebøy

 Nummenhet: Laterale skulder

 C6-nerven (C5-C6 stenose)

 Smerte: Underarm, tommel og pekefinger

 Svakhet: Handleddsekstensjon, biceps

 Nummenhet: Tommel og pekefinger

 C7-nerven (C6-C7 stenose)

 Smerte: Bakside av arm, langfinger

 Svakhet: Triceps, handleddsfleksjon

 Nummenhet: Langfinger

Hvordan diagnostiseres Isjias: Alt du trenger å vite?

Diagnostikk

 

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Diagnostikken baseres primært på sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. En grundig nevrologisk undersøkelse kan ofte lokalisere hvilket niva i ryggen som er affisert.

 Lasegues test (straight leg raise) er den mest prediktive testen for å identifisere kandidater for kirurgi. Testen er positiv når den reproduserer pasientens smerte ved et benløft under 45 grader med utstraling under kneet (StatPearls, 2023).

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR eller CT anbefales ikke rutinemessig. Danske nasjonale retningslinjer frarader rutinemessig bildediagnostikk ved nyoppstått isjias (European Spine Journal, 2018).

 
 Viktig å forstå

 Bildediagnostikk viser ofte normalfunn som slitasje og degenerative forandringer som ikke forklarer smerten. Studier viser at opptil 20-80% av symptomfrie personer har funn på MR som diskusbuling, degenerasjon eller protrusion (StatPearls, 2023).

 

 Bildediagnostikk er indisert ved:

 
 Mistanke om alvorlig patologi (røde flagg)

 Vedvarende symptomer etter 6-8 ukers konservativ behandling

 Ved vurdering av kirurgi

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Skuldersmerter – Komplett guide.

Hvordan kan kiropraktikk hjelpe?

 

 På TheBackROM kombinerer jeg manuell behandling med aktiv rehabilitering. Forskning viser at denne kombinasjonen gir best resultater for de fleste skulderplager.

 
 Manuell behandling

 Jeg bruker ulike teknikker for å forbedre ledd- og muskelfunksjon:

 
 Leddmobilisering for bedre bevegelighet

 Bløtvevsteknikker for spente muskler og triggerpunkter

 Behandling av nakke og brystrygg å mange skulderproblemer henger sammen med stivhet her

 
 

 
 Aktiv rehabilitering

 Øvelser er selve hjØrnesteinen i effektiv skulderbehandling. Forskning viser at strukturerte Øvelsesprogrammer er like effektive som kirurgi for mange tilstander (Kukkonen et al., 2014). Du får:

 
 Spesifikke styrkeøvelser tilpasset din diagnose

 Tøyninger og mobiliseringsØvelser

 HjemmeØvelser du kan gjøre selv mellom behandlingene

 Veiledning om ergonomi og aktivitetstilpasning

 
 

 Hva kan du forvente?

 
 Første konsultasjon (45 minutter)

 Jeg starter alltid med grundig undersøkelse:

 
 Samtale om symptomene dine og hvordan de påvirker hverdagen

 Fysisk undersøkelse av skulder, nakke og rygg

 Testing av styrke og bevegelse

 Klar diagnose og behandlingsplan

 
 

 
 Typiske behandlingstider

 
 Milde plager: 4-6 uker

 Moderate plager: 6-12 uker

 Frossen skulder: 12-24 måneder (men bedring kommer gradvis underveis)

 Kroniske plager: Kan kreve lengre oppfølging

 
 Du vil se gradvis forbedring, ikke plutselig kurering. De fleste trenger 8-12 behandlinger ...

Describe 4. Vestibular Neuritis (3.5-15.5 per 100,000/year) in the context of When Dizziness Doesn't Fit: Is It BPPV or Something Else?.

4. Vestibular Neuritis (3.5-15.5 per 100,000/year)

 Acute inflammation of the balance nerve, often following viral infection.

 
 Sudden onset, severe dizziness

 Persists constantly for days to weeks (not attacks)

 Nausea and vomiting common in acute phase

 Worsened by head movements, but not triggered by specific positions

 Hearing unaffected

 
 BPPV can develop secondary to vestibular neuritis in approximately 10% of cases.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for ICR syndrom.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomene ved ICR syndrom varierer avhengig av underliggende Årsak:

 Lokale symptomer

 
 Ensidig halssmerte: Over carotisarteriens forløp

 Omhet ved palpasjon: Over arterien

 Utstråling: Til kjeve, ore, ansikt, Øye eller hode

 Pulserende smerte: I takt med hjerterytmen

 

 Ved carotisdisseksjon - varselsymptomer

 
 Plutselig, intens hals-/hodepine: Ofte ensidig

 Horners syndrom: Hengende oyelokk, liten pupill, nedsatt svette (på samme side)

 Pulserende tinnitus: Øresus i takt med pulsen

 Synsforstyrrelser: Forbigaende synstap, dobbeltsyn

 TIA-symptomer: Forbigaende svakhet, nummenhet, talevansker

 

 
 Varselsymptomer for hjerneslag

 
 Ensidig svakhet: I ansikt, arm eller ben

Describe causes and risk factors for Thumb Arthritis (CMC.

Causes and risk factors

 Genetics (39-65% hereditary)

 Heredity is by far the most important factor. If your mother has thumb arthritis, your risk is
 significantly increased.

 Gender

 Women are affected 2-3 times more often than men. Hormones and joint laxity play a role.

 Age

 Most common after 50, but X-ray findings can be found as early as the 40s.

 Load

 Heavy manual work and repetitive gripping movements over time increase risk somewhat. This is similar
 to the causation pattern for mouse arm and other overuse conditions in the arm .

Identify red flags for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Red Flags: When Should You Contact a Doctor?

 

 Most cases of C5-C6 disc herniation are harmless and resolve on their own. But some symptoms require
 prompt medical evaluation. See our article on red flags for more
 information.

 
 Seek Medical Attention Immediately For:

 
 Myelopathy signs: Problems with balance and gait, "clumsy" hands, difficulty
 buttoning buttons

 Progressive weakness: Increasing muscle weakness in arm or hand over days

 Bladder/bowel disturbances: Difficulty urinating or controlling urine/stool

 Bilateral symptoms: Numbness or weakness in both arms

 Fever combined with neck stiffness: May indicate infection

 
 These symptoms are rare but require prompt evaluation.

 

 Cervical Myelopathy

 Myelopathy occurs when the herniation or degenerative changes press on the spinal cord itself, not just
 the nerve root. This is more serious than pure radiculopathy and requires faster evaluation.

 
 Signs of Myelopathy

 
 Unsteady gait, especially in the dark

 Difficulty with fine motor skills (writing, buttoning buttons)

 Lhermitte's sign: Electric shock sensation down the spine with neck flexion

 Hyperactive reflexes in the legs

Describe tension headache - the most common headache type for Muscles and Trigger Points That Cause Headache.

Tension Headache - The Most Common Headache Type

 30-78% 
 lifetime prevalence 

 1.5x 
 more common in women 

 3.9 
 trigger points on average 

 In practice, this means that most of us will experience tension headache during our lifetime. Women are affected about 1.5 times more often than men (partly related to hormonal factors ), with the highest occurrence in the 30-49 age group. For some, the symptoms can develop into chronic daily headache .

 What is a Trigger Point?

 A trigger point is an irritated area in a muscle that is hard and tender to touch. What is special about trigger points is that they often cause so-called referred pain - the pain is felt in a different location than where the trigger point actually is.

 On average, patients with chronic tension headache have 3.9 trigger points . Of these, about half are active (cause spontaneous pain) and half are latent (only cause pain when pressed).

Beskriv Hva er hallux rigidus? for Hallux Rigidus (Stiv Storta).

Hva er hallux rigidus?

 

 Hallux rigidus er artrose (slitasjegikt) i stortåens grunnledd - leddet der stortåen fester til mellomfoten. Dette leddet er helt avgjørende for normal gange, da det bøyes opptil 60 grader ved hvert skritt.

 Når brusken i leddet slites ned, oppstar betennelse, smerter og etter hvert beindannelse (osteofytter) rundt leddet. Disse beinpalsene begrenser bevegelsen ytterligere og kan gi en synlig kul på toppen av leddet.

 
 
 2,5%
 over 50 Ør rammes
 

 
 1 av 40
 voksne totalt
 

 
 80%
 har det i begge fotter
 

 
 50-60
 vanligste alder
 

 

 Graderingssystem

 Hallux rigidus klassifiseres vanligvis i fire stadier:

 
 
 
 Grad
 Bevegelse
 Røntgenfunn
 Symptomer
 
 
 
 
 Grad 0-1
 Lett redusert
 Minimale forandringer
 Periodiske smerter ved aktivitet
 
 
 Grad 2
 Moderat redusert (30-50 grader)
 Osteofytter, leddspaltereduksjon
 Smerter ved bevegelse, hevelse
 
 
 Grad 3
 Betydelig redusert (< 30 grader)
 Store osteofytter, betydelig artrose
 Konstante smerter, endret gangmønster
 
 
 Grad 4
 Minimal eller ingen
 Komplett artrose
 Alvorlig funksjonshemming

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Jaw Exercises and Home Treatment for TMD.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How often should I do the exercises?

 Most protocols recommend 4-6 times daily. The Rocabado program uses 6 repetitions, 6 times daily. Short sessions spread throughout the day are more effective than one long session.

 

 
 Should it hurt during exercises?

 No. Mild discomfort or stretch is fine, but sharp pain means you're pushing too hard. Reduce intensity and talk to your practitioner if pain persists.

 

 
 Do bite splints help?

 Bite splints (stabilization splints) have about the same effect as exercises on pain according to research (Zhang et al., 2021). The advantage of exercises is that they are free and give faster improvement - on average 10 weeks earlier.

 

 
 Can I exercise with TMD?

 Yes, but avoid exercises that stress the jaw. Contact sports, swimming with lots of rotation and activities where you clench your teeth can temporarily worsen symptoms.

 

 
 How long must I continue with exercises?

 After symptoms are under control, maintenance exercises 1-2 times daily long-term are recommended. TMD has a high relapse rate, and prevention is easier than treatment.

 

 
 Should I get imaging (MRI/X-ray)?

 Usually not. Imaging often shows normal findings like wear and degeneration that don't explain the pain. Clinical examination is more important. Imaging is only relevant when serious pathology is suspected.

 

 
 Can stress alone cause TMD?

 Stress is one of the most important risk factors. Many tighten the jaw and ...

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness).

Symptoms

 

 Typical Presentation:

 
 Diffuse unsteadiness or swaying feeling lasting minutes to hours

 Feeling that the head is "heavy" or "clumsy"

 Worsening with prolonged sitting, especially in front of a computer screen

 Neck pain or stiffness occurring together with the dizziness

 Headache starting in the neck and radiating forward

 Mild nausea (rarely severe vomiting)

 

 What Does NOT Fit with Cervicogenic Dizziness:

 
 Short, intense spinning attacks (10-60 sec): Suggests BPPV

 Hearing loss or tinnitus: Points to vestibular pathology like Meniere's disease or vestibular neuritis

 Severe attacks with light/sound sensitivity: Vestibular migraine

 Neurological symptoms: Double vision, speech difficulties - requires immediate evaluation

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How high should the screen be to avoid shoulder pain?

 The top of the screen should be at eye level or slightly below. This means you
 look straight ahead or slightly down, which provides a relaxed neck and shoulder position.

 

 
 Can mouse use cause shoulder pain?

 Yes. If the mouse is placed too far out to the side or too high, you have to
 extend your arm and raise your shoulder. Over time, this can cause tension and pain in the shoulder
 and neck.

 

 
 How often should I take breaks from computer work?

 Ideally, you should take a micro-break (30-60 seconds) every 20-30 minutes, and
 a longer break (5-10 minutes) every hour. Movement and variation are key.

 

 
 Is a standing desk better for the shoulders?

 Variation is more important than whether you sit or stand. A sit-stand desk
 allows you to alternate between positions throughout the day, which is beneficial for both shoulder,
 neck and back.

 

 
 What exercises can I do at my desk?

 Good exercises include shoulder rolls, neck stretches, chest opening and
 shoulder blade squeeze. These only take a few seconds and can be done sitting at your desk.

 

 
 Does ergonomic equipment help?

 Ergonomic equipment (mouse, keyboard, chair) can help, but it's not magic. The
 most important thing is correct setup of what you have, and above all breaks and movement. Expensive
 equipment doesn't replace good habits.

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck.

Symptoms

 

 Typical Symptoms

 
 Radicular pain: Sharp, burning, or electric pain that radiates from neck to arm
 

 Numbness and tingling: Often in specific fingers depending on which nerve is
 affected

 Weakness: Reduced strength in specific arm or hand muscles

 Neck stiffness: Especially with movements that close the foramen (extension +
 rotation toward painful side)

 

 
 Spurling's Test

 A classic test for foraminal stenosis: The head
 is bent backward and rotated toward the painful side, then light pressure is applied downward. A
 positive test reproduces radiation to the arm. This "closes" the foramen and provokes symptoms.

What is the prognosis for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know?

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?

 

 Here's the good news: the prognosis for sciatica is generally good, but it often takes longer than many
 think.

 
 The positive:

 
 The majority improve without surgery

 50% experience significant improvement within 4 weeks

 55-70% have recovered within a year

 Disc herniations can shrink and be reabsorbed over time

 
 

 
 The realistic:

 
 Median time to improvement is 10-12 weeks - not 6 weeks

 20-30% have persistent symptoms after 1-2 years

 Recurrence affects about 1 in 4 within a few years

Explain chiropractic treatment and rehabilitation for Rotator Cuff — Complete Guide to the Rotator Cuff.

Chiropractic treatment and rehabilitation

 At TheBackROM, I combine manual therapy with active rehabilitation. Research shows that this combination produces good results for rotator cuff-related shoulder complaints.

 What can a chiropractor do?

 Thorough examination: Clinical tests to identify which structures are affected and the degree of severity

 Individualised exercise programme: Tailored to your injury type, pain level and functional demands

 Joint mobilisation: Improved mobility in the shoulder, thoracic spine and neck — compensatory stiffness often worsens the problem

 Soft tissue treatment: Working on tight musculature around the shoulder and scapula

 Rehabilitation guidance: Gradual progression back to normal activities

 Thoracic spine and neck — the forgotten connection

 Many people with rotator cuff problems have stiffness in the thoracic spine and/or neck that contributes to overloading the shoulder. When the thoracic spine is stiff, the shoulder must compensate with more movement. Treatment of the thoracic spine and neck can therefore be an important part of rehabilitation.

 What can you do yourself?

 Pendulum exercises: Lean forward, let the arm hang and swing gently in circles. 2-3 times daily

 Isometric external rotation: Stand with the elbow at 90 degrees against a door frame. Press outward without movement. Hold 10 sec, 10 repetitions

 Scapular squeeze: Pull the shoulder blades back and down. Hold 5 sec, 10 repetitions, 3 times daily

 Ice after activity: 15-20 minutes when pain worsens

 Sleeping position: Sleeping on the healthy side with a pillow under the affected arm can relieve night pain

Describe Headache through the lifespan for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine.

Headache through the lifespan

 

 Hormonal headache changes throughout life in step with the major hormonal shifts:

 
 
 Menarche (first period)

 Migraine often debuts in puberty. Before puberty, migraine is equally common in boys and girls - afterward it becomes 3x more common in women.

 

 
 Fertile years

 Menstrual migraine is most common. Many experience that attacks are worst during the first days of the period. Birth control can both help and worsen.

 

 
 Pregnancy

 60-70% experience improvement, especially in the 2nd and 3rd trimester when hormone levels are stable and high. Some experience onset or worsening.

 

 
 After birth

 Rapid drop in estrogen can cause migraine relapse shortly after birth. Breastfeeding can provide protection due to stable hormones.

 

 
 Perimenopause

 Often a difficult period with unpredictable fluctuations. Many experience worsening of migraine during this phase.

 

 
 After menopause

 Many experience significant improvement or their migraine disappears when hormone levels stabilize at a lower level.

Explain treatment of thrower's shoulder for Thrower's Shoulder and GIRD: When Throwing Causes Shoulder Pain.

Treatment of Thrower's Shoulder

 Conservative treatment is very effective for thrower's shoulder, with over 90% success rate. The main
 goals are to restore normal movement and strength.

 Treatment principles

 Posterior capsule stretching: Sleeper stretch is the main intervention

 Posterior rotator cuff strengthening: Infraspinatus, teres minor

 Scapular stabilization: Shoulder blade control

 Gradual return to throwing: Structured throwing program

 Phase 1: Acute phase (0-2 weeks)

 Relative rest from throwing

 Daily posterior capsule stretching

 Soft tissue treatment of infraspinatus and teres minor

 Ice after activity as needed

 Phase 2: Rehabilitation phase (2-6 weeks)

 Continued stretching with focus on reaching normal values

 Progressive strength training for rotator cuff

 Scapula exercises (serratus anterior, lower trapezius)

 General shoulder and core training

 Phase 3: Return to throwing (6-12 weeks)

 Structured throwing program with gradual progression

 Start with short distances and low intensity

 Increase distance and power over several weeks

 Full maintenance program to prevent recurrence

 Main exercises

 Sleeper Stretch (main exercise for GIRD)

 Lie on the affected side with shoulder at 90 degrees flexion

 Elbow bent 90 degrees, forearm pointing up

 Use opposite hand to gently press forearm down toward floor

 Hold stretch for 30-60 seconds

 Repeat 3-4 times, 2-3 times daily

 Important: Avoid letting the shoulder roll backward. Keep shoulder blade stable
 against the surface.

Beskriv årsaker for Occipital nevralgi.

Årsaker

 Occipital nevralgi kan ha mange årsaker, men i mange tilfeller finner man ingen tydelig underliggende årsak (idiopatisk). De vanligste kjente årsakene inkluderer
 Muskelspenninger og triggerpunkter (Vanligst)

 Stramme muskler i øvre nakke kan komprimere occipitalnervene der de passerer gjennom muskulaturen. Særlig semispinalis capitis, trapezius og sternocleidomastoideus. Les mer om triggerpunkter og hodepine .

 Nakkeskader (whiplash)

 Traumer mot nakken kan skade eller irritere occipitalnervene, enten direkte eller gjennom påfølgende muskelspasmer og arrdannelse.

 Artrose i øvre nakkevirvler

 Degenerative forandringer i C1-C3 kan påvirke nervene som danner occipitalnervene. Osteoartritt eller beinsporer kan komprimere nervene.

 Langvarig dårlig holdning

 Fremoverlent hode (f.eks. ved kontorarbeid) kan over tid føre til muskelspenninger og nerveaffeksjon i øvre nakke. Dette kan også bidra til nakkehodepine .

 Andre årsaker

 Betennelse (gikt, diabetes, vaskulitt)

 Infeksjoner

 Svulster (sjelden)

 Komplikasjoner etter nakkekirurgi

Clinical summary of Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

Summary

 What it is: Injury to the tendon that supports the foot arch (tibialis posterior)

 Consequence: Most common cause of acquired flat foot in adults

 Prognosis: Good with early treatment (stage 1-2)

 Important: Progressive condition - early treatment is crucial

 Consultation: 45 min first visit, 30 min follow-up
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Common tests in the context of Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Common tests

 
 Palpation of sit bone - tenderness with pressure

 Bent-knee stretch - pain with stretching with bent knee

 Puranen-Orava test - active hamstring contraction

 Single leg bridge - often reproduces the pain

 
 

 Imaging

 
 MRI - can show tendon thickening and edema

 Ultrasound - useful for seeing tendon changes

 X-ray - can show bone deposits (enthesophytes)

 

 Imaging is not always necessary. Many are effectively treated based on clinical findings
 alone.

 Differential diagnoses

 
 Sciatica - from the spine

 Piriformis syndrome - pain higher in the
 buttock

 SI joint dysfunction - pelvic joint pain

 Stress fracture in pelvis - rare

 
 

 
 
 5
 Treatment

 

 Progressive strength training is key

 Research shows that heavy, progressive strength training is the well-documented treatment
 for PHT.

 
 Treatment principles:

 
 Start with isometric exercises (holding position)

 Gradually build up to heavier loads

 Focus on strength, NOT stretching

 Be patient - this takes time

 
 

 Phase 1: Pain control (weeks 1-2)

 
 Reduce compression - avoid prolonged sitting on hard chairs

 Use a cushion - relieve the sit bone

 Isometric exercises - hamstring activation without movement

 Avoid stretching!

 

 Phase 2: Strength building (weeks 2-8)

 
 Bridging progressions - from two-leg to single-leg

 Romanian deadlift - controlled hip flexion

 Nordic hamstring curl - eccentric strength

 Hip thrust - gluteal activation

 

 Phase 3: Functional training (weeks 8-12+)

 
 High loads - 80-90% of maximum strength

 Explosive training - jumps, sprints

 Running-specific training - gradual return

 

 Manual treatment

 
 Soft tissue treatment - can relieve muscle tension

 Pelvic and hip mobilization

 Nerve mobilization - for nerve irritation

 

 When is injection/surgery considered?

 
 Cortisone injection - can provide short-term relief, not first choice

 PRP injection - uncertain effect

 Surgery - rare, only for long-term failure of conservative treatment

 
 

 
 
 6
 Prognosis

 

 PHT is known to be a long-lasting condition, but most recover with patience and proper
 treatment.

 What can you expect?

 
 Weeks 1-4: Pain reduction with load management

 Months 1-3: Gradual strength building

 Months 3-6: Return to activity

 Up to 12 months: For long-standing cases

 

 Factors that affect prognosis

 
 Duration before treatment - early diagnosis gives better prognosis

 Compliance with strength program - necessary for recovery

 Avoiding stretching - many set themselves back by stretching

 Gradual return - too rapid progression causes relapse

 

 
 Relapses are common

 Many experience relapses, especially with too rapid progression of training. This is normal and does
 not mean treatment has failed. Adjust down, build up again - patience is key.

Identify red flags for Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

Red Flags - When Dizziness Is Serious

 

 
 Call emergency services immediately if you experience:

 
 Difficulty speaking (dysarthria)

 Facial weakness or numbness

 Double vision (diplopia)

 Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)

 Severe headache ("thunderclap headache")

 Weakness in arm or leg

 
 These symptoms may indicate stroke and require immediate evaluation.

 

 The five D's that warn of central problems: Diplopia, Dysarthria, Dysphagia, Dysmetria, Drop attacks.

Prevention and Long-term Strategies

 Workplace Ergonomics

 Screen height: Top edge at eye level

 Screen distance: Arm's length away

 Chair height: Feet flat on floor, knees at 90 degrees

 Phone Use

 Limit prolonged scrolling

 Alternate between hands

 Sleep Position

 Avoid stomach sleeping (rotates neck maximally)

 Side sleeping with supportive pillow that fills the gap between shoulder and head

 Back sleeping with thin pillow under neck

What causes Hip Labral Tear?

Causes

 

 FAI (Femoroacetabular impingement)

 The most common cause of labral tear. With FAI (hip
 impingement), there is an abnormal shape of the femoral head (cam) or hip socket (pincer) that
 causes the labrum to be pinched during certain movements.

 Other causes

 
 Sports injuries - especially rotational sports like football, hockey, dance

 Acute trauma - falls, collisions

 Overuse - repetitive movements over time

 Hypermobility - overly mobile joints that increase wear

 Hip dysplasia - congenital shallow hip socket

 Degeneration - natural aging

 

 Risk factors

 
 Sports with deep hip flexion - yoga, martial arts, hockey

 Rotational sports - golf, tennis, football

 Dancers and gymnasts - extreme mobility

 FAI (cam/pincer) - structural abnormality

Why does stress settle in the neck?: When you experience stress, the brain sends signals that activate the musculature. This is part of the body's "fight or flight" response. The problem is that modern stressors rarely require physical action - but the muscle tension remains.

How common is stress neck?: Women are affected more often than men - nearly double the risk of neck pain in women.

Treatment: A network meta-analysis from 2024 shows that manual therapy provides short-term improvement in pain, pressure sensitivity and function for trigger points. Treatment includes
Frequently Asked Questions: Yes. EMG studies clearly show that mental stress increases muscle activity in trapezius. There is no contradiction between "psychological" stress and "physical" pain - the body reacts to both.

Describe What is Dizziness? for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

What is Dizziness?

 

 Dizziness isn't one thing. It's an umbrella term covering several different experiences:

 
 Three Types of Dizziness

 
 Vertigo: The sensation that you or your surroundings are rotating. The room spins,
 or you feel like you're spinning even though you're standing still. This almost always stems from
 disturbances in the balance organ.

 Unsteadiness: Often described as a swaying or rocking feeling - like standing on a
 boat deck. You don't feel quite stable on your feet.

 Light-headedness: A diffuse feeling of being "foggy" in the head. Some describe it
 as almost fainting.

 
 

 How Balance Works

 Three systems continuously send information to the brain:

 
 
 👂

 Balance Organ

 In the inner ear - registers the head's movements and position

 

 
 👁

 Eyes

 Tell the brain where you are in relation to your surroundings

 

 
 🦶

 Body Sense

 Sensors in muscles, tendons and joints report the body's position

 

 

 When all three systems send matching signals, you feel stable. When one system sends incorrect
 information - or the systems send conflicting signals - dizziness occurs.

Describe Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected? for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected?

 

 The inner ear has three semicircular canals on each side:

 
 Posterior Canal (80-90% of cases)

 By far the most common form. Diagnosed with the Dix-Hallpike test and treated with the Epley or Semont maneuver.

 

 
 Horizontal/Lateral Canal (5-30%, possibly up to 46%)

 May be underdiagnosed. Treated with Barbecue roll (Lempert) or Gufoni maneuver.

 

 
 Anterior Canal (1-3%)

 The rarest form. Crystals rarely fall upward due to anatomical position.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Severs Syndrom.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomene utvikler seg typisk gradvis og forverres med aktivitet.

 Vanlige symptomer

 
 Smerter i haelen - typisk bak og under haelen

 Forverres ved aktivitet - spesielt loping og hopping

 Halting - spesielt etter trening

 Stivhet om morgenen eller etter hvile

 Omhet ved trykk på sidene av haelen

 Gang på ta - barnet ungår å belaste haelen

 

 
 Typisk mønster

 Smertene er ofte verst:

 
 Under og etter trening

 Ved loping på hardt underlag

 Ved bruk av fotbalsko eller andre sportssko med lav hælhøyde

 I perioder med rask vekst

 
 

 
 Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen stilles klinisk basert på sykehistorie og undersøkelse. Den klassiske "squeeze-testen" (smerter ved å klemme på sidene av haelen) er typisk positiv.

 Røntgen er vanligvis ikke nødvendig, men kan tas for å utelukke andre tilstander.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Sever's Disease.

What is Sever's Disease?: Sever's disease is an overuse condition that affects the growth plate (apophysis) in the heel bone of
 children. The Achilles tendon attaches here, and with repeated stress, the area can become irritated and
 painful. This is different from stress fracture in the foot , which
 involves an actual bone break.

Symptoms: Symptoms typically develop gradually and worsen with activity.

Causes and Risk Factors: Sever's disease typically occurs when several factors are present at the same time. Many of these risk
 factors can also contribute to ankle sprains and other foot problems in
 young athletes.

Is Sever's Disease Dangerous?: No, Sever's disease is completely harmless and causes no permanent damage. It is a
 common, benign growth pain that resolves on its own when the growth plate in the heel closes.

Red Flags - When You Must See a Doctor: These symptoms may indicate
 other conditions that require further investigation.

Treatment: The goal of treatment is to reduce pain so that the child can maintain activity. Complete rest is rarely
 necessary.

Prognosis and Expected Course: The prognosis is excellent. All children with Sever's disease fully recover when the
 growth plate closes.
